segment.source: Monitor user and device claims during sign-in (Windows 10)
segment.target: Monitor user and device claims during sign-in (Windows 10)

segment.source: This topic for the IT professional describes how to monitor user and device claims that are associated with a user’s security token when you are using advanced security auditing options to monitor dynamic access control objects.
segment.target: This topic for the IT professional describes how to monitor user and device claims that are associated with a user’s security token when you are using advanced security auditing options to monitor dynamic access control objects.

segment.source: Monitor user and device claims during sign-in
segment.target: Monitor user and device claims during sign-in

segment.source: Applies to
segment.target: Applies to

segment.source: Windows 10
segment.target: Windows 10

segment.source: This topic for the IT professional describes how to monitor user and device claims that are associated with a user’s security token when you are using advanced security auditing options to monitor dynamic access control objects.
segment.target: This topic for the IT professional describes how to monitor user and device claims that are associated with a user’s security token when you are using advanced security auditing options to monitor dynamic access control objects.

segment.source: Device claims are associated with the system that is used to access resources that are protected with Dynamic Access Control.
segment.target: Device claims are associated with the system that is used to access resources that are protected with Dynamic Access Control.

segment.source: User claims are attributes that are associated with a user.
segment.target: User claims are attributes that are associated with a user.

segment.source: User claims and device claims are included in the user’s security token used at sign-on.
segment.target: User claims and device claims are included in the user’s security token used at sign-on.

segment.source: For example, information about Department, Company, Project, or Security clearances might be included in the token.
segment.target: For example, information about Department, Company, Project, or Security clearances might be included in the token.

segment.source: Use the following procedures to monitor changes to user claims and device claims in the user’s sign-on token and to verify the changes.
segment.target: Use the following procedures to monitor changes to user claims and device claims in the user’s sign-on token and to verify the changes.

segment.source: These procedures assume that you have configured and deployed Dynamic Access Control, including central access policies, claims, and other components, in your network.
segment.target: These procedures assume that you have configured and deployed Dynamic Access Control, including central access policies, claims, and other components, in your network.

segment.source: If you have not yet deployed Dynamic Access Control in your network, see Deploy a Central Access Policy (Demonstration Steps).
segment.target: If you have not yet deployed Dynamic Access Control in your network, see Deploy a Central Access Policy (Demonstration Steps).

segment.source: Note: Your server might function differently based on the version and edition of the operating system that is installed, your account permissions, and your menu settings.
segment.target: Note: Your server might function differently based on the version and edition of the operating system that is installed, your account permissions, and your menu settings.

segment.source: To monitor user and device claims in user logon token
segment.target: To monitor user and device claims in user logon token

segment.source: Sign in to your domain controller by using domain administrator credentials.
segment.target: Sign in to your domain controller by using domain administrator credentials.

segment.source: In Server Manager, point to Tools, and then click Group Policy Management.
segment.target: In Server Manager, point to Tools, and then click Group Policy Management.

segment.source: In the console tree, right-click the flexible access Group Policy Object, and then click Edit.
segment.target: In the console tree, right-click the flexible access Group Policy Object, and then click Edit.

segment.source: Double-click Computer Configuration, click Security Settings, expand Advanced Audit Policy Configuration, expand System Audit Policies, click Logon/Logoff, and then double-click Audit User/Device claims.
segment.target: Double-click Computer Configuration, click Security Settings, expand Advanced Audit Policy Configuration, expand System Audit Policies, click Logon/Logoff, and then double-click Audit User/Device claims.

segment.source: Select the Configure the following audit events check box, select the Success check box (and the Failure check box, if desired), and then click OK.
segment.target: Select the Configure the following audit events check box, select the Success check box (and the Failure check box, if desired), and then click OK.

segment.source: Close the Group Policy Management Editor.
segment.target: Close the Group Policy Management Editor.

segment.source: After you configure settings to monitor user and device claims, verify that the changes are being monitored.
segment.target: After you configure settings to monitor user and device claims, verify that the changes are being monitored.

segment.source: To verify that user and device claims in user logon token are monitored
segment.target: To verify that user and device claims in user logon token are monitored

segment.source: With local administrator credentials, sign in to a file server that is subject to the flexible access Group Policy Object.
segment.target: With local administrator credentials, sign in to a file server that is subject to the flexible access Group Policy Object.

segment.source: Open an elevated command prompt, and run the following command:
segment.target: Open an elevated command prompt, and run the following command:

segment.source: From a client computer, connect to a file share on the file server as a user who has access permissions to the file server.
segment.target: From a client computer, connect to a file share on the file server as a user who has access permissions to the file server.

segment.source: On the file server, open Event Viewer, expand Windows Logs, and select the Security log.
segment.target: On the file server, open Event Viewer, expand Windows Logs, and select the Security log.

segment.source: Look for event 4626, and confirm that it contains information about user claims and device claims.
segment.target: Look for event 4626, and confirm that it contains information about user claims and device claims.

segment.source: Related resource
segment.target: Related resource

segment.source: Using advanced security auditing options to monitor dynamic access control objects
segment.target: Using advanced security auditing options to monitor dynamic access control objects
